FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This report contains the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the ammonia refrigeration systems located at the Americold-Dallas cold storage facility in Dallas, TX.   The RMP  was prepared in accordance with the requirements of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RM program) regulation (Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention, 40 CFR Part 68).

Mr. Randell Willaims, Regional Compliance Manager, coordinated the preparation of the RMP with Price McNutt the Facility Service Manager of the Americold-Dallas facility. The information presented in this report reflects the facility data for elements of the EPA RMP release prevention program and Off Site Consequence analysis.  This was done through the E-submit portal of EPA's central data exchange server.  

Americold recognizes management's responsibility in protecting its employees, equipment, property, and the environment.  The safety and health of all personnel are first and foremost very important.  The prevention of accidental releases has been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the Dallas facility.

To accomplish the goal to prevent accidents, the facility has an established Process Safety Management Program (PSM).  The objectives of the PSM Program are to: prevent ammonia releases, roff site impacts, harm to public and environmental receptors, maximize efficiency and improve safety performance, reduce losses associated with damage of property, eliminate human suffering and the economic burden resulting from injuries and accidents.

One of the activities associated with the PSM Program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency planning initiatives which are designed to comply with EPA 68.90-95 and OSHA 1910.38 Emergency Action Plan.
The purpose of the accidental release prevention and emergency response programs is to prevent the occurrence, and minim

ize the consequences of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall, these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.

The accidental release prevention and emergency planning programs help prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices which govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and improved as (often as) necessary.  They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at the facility.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Americold operates the cold storage facility in Dallas, TX.  The facility operates two ammonia refrigeration systems (i. e., the Building 1 and Building 2 Refrigeration Systems) to provide cooling and freezing capabilities.  The amount of anhydrous ammonia (CAS #7662-41-7) contained in one of these systems is above the EPA's threshold of 10,000 pounds.  The maximum intended amount of ammonia charged to the Building 1 and 2 Refrigeration Systems is 10,800 and 9,900 pounds respectively. The average daily quantity of ammonia is calculated to be below the maximum reported on this RMP submission. 

Summary of Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios

Building 1 and 2 Refrigeration System

A worst-case release scenario was modeled for the Building 1 and 2 refrigeration systems at the Dallas facility in order to determine the off site impacts to public and environmental receptors. 

The worst-case release scenario related to the refrigeration systems is unlikely for the following reasons:

The worst-case weather conditions which were used for this scenario are not typical;
The controlled pressure receiver is located in an enclosed area that could help to contain such a release and minimize traffic (e. g.; forklifts) near the receiver;
Industry standards have been followed for the manufacture and

ntractors are screened and evaluated before they perform work on or near the ammonia refrigeration system.  The contractors are also periodically evaluated to ensure that they perform work by following safe work practices.

	 	Pre-Startup Safety Review: A pre-startup safety review is completed for all new ammonia projects to verify that all applicable safety programs are in place, training has been performed, and construction has been completed according to design standards before the project is put into use.

	 	Mechanical Integrity:  This program ensures that the ammonia refrigeration systems are built and maintained using preventive maintenance procedures to minimize unexpected breakdowns or failures.

	 	Hot Work Permit: These procedures ensure that a signed permit is obtained prior to any cutting, welding, or burning.

	 	Management of Change: The procedures are designed to ensure that all changes made to the ammonia refrigeration system are properly reviewed.

	 	Incident Investigation: The procedures ensure that any incidents (and near misses) are investigated, reviewed, and documented using an investigation team.

	 	Compliance Audits: There are procedures to conduct regular audits of the RMP program to ensure that the program is in place and working properly.

   Five-Year Accident History

There have been no ammonia-related incidents at the Americold Dallas facility within the last five years that have resulted in any onsite or offsite impacts.

   Description of the Emergency Response Program

An emergency action plan has been implemented at the Dallas facility.  This program contains procedures describing how the facility will respond to ammonia spills and other emergencies, including evacuation procedures.  Due to the limited staffing for emergency response program, the emergency response plan has been coordinated with the Dallas Fire Dept. and the Dallas County LEPC.

The emergency planning consists of the following elements:

Organization Plan and Responsibilities
	 	Communications Procedures
	 	Detailed Action Plans
	 	First Aid Procedures
	 	Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures
	 	Evacuation Plans
	 	Description of Outside Assistance Available
	 	Training Programs and Drills

   Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Several recommendations to improve safety were made for either the equipment (hardware recommendations) or the system operating procedures (procedural recommendations) when a process hazard analysis (PHA) study was carried out on 4/20/2011 for the  ammonia refrigeration system at the Dallas facility.  The recommended changes have been evaluated by management and are being addressed and will be resolved in a timely manner.
